files.patch:
@@ -33,1 +33,0 @@ -| [New Feature]{.jbs-value} | Not recommended for use. | @@ -37,0 +36,1 @@ +| [New Feature]{.jbs-value} | Not recommended for use. | @@ -266,1 +266,1 @@ -| [Fixed]{.jbs-value} | [Resolved]{.jbs-value} / [Closed]{.jbs-value} | The [Fixed]{.jbs-value} resolution should be used **only** if a change has been integrated in a repo to address the issue. For the JDK project in almost all cases the bots will transition the issue to [Resolved]{.jbs-value}/[Fixed]{.jbs-value} when the changeset is pushed to the repo. An issue in [Resolved]{.jbs-value}/[Fixed]{.jbs-value} state needs to go through [verification](#verifying-an-issue) to end up as [Closed]{.jbs-value}/[Fixed]{.jbs-value}.
If there isn't a fix in the repo (and so no associated changeset) then the issue should not be marked as [Fixed]{.jbs-field}. | +| [Fixed]{.jbs-value} | [Resolved]{.jbs-value} / [Closed]{.jbs-value} | The [Fixed]{.jbs-value} resolution should be used **only** if a change has been integrated in a repo to address the issue. For the JDK project in almost all cases the bots will transition the issue to [Resolved]{.jbs-value}/[Fixed]{.jbs-value} when the changeset is pushed to the repo. An issue in [Resolved]{.jbs-value}/[Fixed]{.jbs-value} state needs to go through [verification](#verifying-an-issue) to end up as [Closed]{.jbs-value}/[Fixed]{.jbs-value}.
If there isn't a fix in the repo (and so no associated changeset) then the issue should **not** be marked as [Fixed]{.jbs-field}. | @@ -286,1 +286,3 @@ -**Note:** Any issue closed as a [Duplicate]{.jbs-value} **must** have a "Duplicates" link to the duplicating issue. +::: {.note} +Any issue closed as a [Duplicate]{.jbs-value} **must** have a "Duplicates" link to the duplicating issue. +:::
